comment_body: @mihirpat1 please specify the real need. i.e we sometime need to support non-standard optics not compliant to the spec

> @mihirpat1 please specify the real need. i.e we sometime need to support non-standard optics not compliant to the spec

@prgeor - Updated the description now.
@donboll FYI
@saiarcot895 , could you please help review it? Thanks.

> Saving power is a good thing today, so without a good reason I am against changing defaults for all devices. The commit message does not even say, what the problem is, and also does not mention a device.

@volodymyrsamotiy can you add the missing information? Please elaborate the issue and the necessity of having this change.
@yxieca please merge to fix SATA issue
@saiarcot895 can you please help to merge?
@volodymyrsamotiy Please add details of the issue to this PR and to #363 (which has already been merged).
@saiarcot895 @prgeor Can you please review and signoff?
Moved to draft since testing is still in progress, once testing is finished will updated PR.

Please note that the kernel will be upgraded to 6.1 shortly. Because of that, this PR may need to be modified to be merged directly into 202305 (and backported from there), and a separate PR raised for master branch/202311 for the 6.1 kernel.

Thanks, I created separate PRs for 202205 & 202305
- https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linux-kernel/pull/365
- https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linux-kernel/pull/366
@prgeor , can you check?
@saiarcot895 can you please help to merge?
What problem does this solve? Performance? On what device did you see performance issues?
I had asked the same question in https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linux-kernel/pull/366.

Is this related to the SDK update?

@yxieca Can you please review and merge this.

Looks like there are compile errors:

@saiarcot895 can we merge this?
Why not merge the master branch instead?
It’d be great if you shared your rebase command.

@paulmenzel This was to resolve some conflicts that would occur with the next rebase onto the top of the master branch. The rebase was done through Github's UI (there's an option to do a rebase and merge on top of the target branch).
This branch will get merged into master branch in the near future as well.

@Pavan-Nokia please review
Please elaborate in the git commit message, and also add notes how the remaining patches are going to be upstreamed.
@Keshavg-marvell As Paul mentioned, is there any update on the upstreaming of the remaining patches?

For the up-streamed commits we are addressing one by one. 
To start with for sonic-linux-kernel PR https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linux-kernel/pull/337 - the below PR is raised against  kernel.org 
https://lore.kernel.org/linux-devicetree/20231024131935.2567969-1-enachman@marvell.com/T/#u

The changes  here in this PR are the existing patches and adapted to new kernel which were not getting applied cleanly
due to api, api-signature, file format changes etc in new kernel. Here we are also renumbering
series file. So due to file renaming and resolution of patch somehow for some of patch git 
is taking it as deleted and added instead of showing renamed.  
for ex below patch.  
"patch/0016-ac5-marvell-Add-support-for-emmc.patch (showing deleted)  -> patch/0006-ac5-marvell-Add-support-for-emmc.patch (added)"
@saiarcot895 Please see if you can approve and merge this review.

@StormLiangMS Can you please help to merge these changes? These are backport of https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linux-kernel/pull/336
This is an infra level change which is used to automate integration of Nvidia components as is not part of the compiled kernel itself.

> Thank you for the patches. Two things:
> 
> 1. Could you please comment, when patches 3 and 4 are going to be upstreamed?
> 2. Could you please rebase the changes with only three commits: recreate patches 1 and 2, move the patches for the marker, and add patch 4?

They are downstream patches and won't be upstreamed. The patches 0003 & 0004 offer logically separate functionality and so i don't think it is a good idea to merge 0003 & 0004 together

`\Add nvidia arm markers and add an ability to patch kconfig-inc` has a stray leading `\`.

Could you please elaborate more, and add commit messages? Markers seem to make the build system even more complicated.

> `\Add nvidia arm markers and add an ability to patch kconfig-inc` has a stray leading `\`.
> 
> Could you please elaborate more, and add commit messages? Markers seem to make the build system even more complicated.

We have automatic infrastructure which depend on markers to effectively make changes to these files. They are just comments and doesn't affect the build process. I've mentioned other changes made in the PR description.

Thanks for providing the link. Will check.

> 
> Have you sent these patches upstream for review? SONiC does not have the expertise to review such big patch sets. (It’s also hard to do in GitHub’s Web interface as the patches are too big.)

There is an ongoing work on upstreaming the changes to linux-kernel 6.x (For ex: Pls see https://lore.kernel.org/lkml/20230410184526.15990-1-blarson@amd.com/).. 
There are no plans to backport to 5.10.x in upstream.

I will update.

I had split the patch from our internal 5.10 kernel into mostly per subsystem changes. All the changes in drivers/soc/pensando are part of this change.

@saiarcot895 , i checked the build log for arm64, did we build the patch for pensando? cannot see if those patch files are built.

> @saiarcot895 , i checked the build log for arm64, did we build the patch for pensando? cannot see if those patch files are built.

No, the pipeline builds assume that the kernel is the same regardless of platform, which is fine for amd64, but is not true for the armhf and arm64 kernels. Because of that, we don't have pipeline builds for the different armhf and arm64 platforms (this includes Marvell and Nokia).

> > > > Thank you for the patches. Please follow [How to Write a Git Commit Message](https://cbea.ms/git-commit/) and the Linux kernel documentation on how to write commit messages. Also the Signed-off-by lines is missing.

Patches which are similar (with minor modifications for 5.10.x kernel) to upstream which are already merged has been marked as [upstrem commit-id] in the patchset. Rest of the patches are ported from dsc-linux-patches repo which are maintained for 5.4.x kernel.
@saiarcot895 , got it. Then i think @ashwin-h, in this pr, can you also change the azp pipeline to get it build?

> This merge/pull requests consists now of two (sonic-linux-kernel) commits with the same commit message summary (besides capitalization) and no commit message body.
> 
> As these are so many patches, and SONiC has the upstream policy, please document your plans on upstreaming. The last attempt seems to have been made by Brad in January 2023. It is the middle of July now. Several of the 29 patches – besides the few already in Linus’ master/main branch – could also (and should) be upstreamed right away. The script `scripts/get_maintainer.pl` helps you to find the addresses to send them to.

The upstream work is in progress from our team (mostly by Brad as u mentioned).

The latest commit addresses the review comments.

> @saiarcot895 , got it. Then i think @ashwin-h, in this pr, can you also change the azp pipeline to get it build?

@lguohan i have no idea about azp pipeline build. Is there any doc on how to add ?

azp pipeline file for this repo is here. https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linux-kernel/tree/master/.azure-pipelines

more info here. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/get-started/what-is-azure-pipelines?view=azure-devops

Hi @ashwin-h, FYI, the next SONiC branch (202311) will have Linux 6.1. There will also be a kernel update to 5.10.179 going in in the near future.

There will almost certainly be changes to these patches needed for Linux 6.1; I'm hoping that for the upgrade to 5.10.179, not too many changes will be needed.

> Hi @ashwin-h, FYI, the next SONiC branch (202311) will have Linux 6.1. There will also be a kernel update to 5.10.179 going in in the near future.
> 
> There will almost certainly be changes to these patches needed for Linux 6.1; I'm hoping that for the upgrade to 5.10.179, not too many changes will be needed.

Thanks @saiarcot895 for the heads-up. I tried patching the changes on 5.10.179 (vanilla kernel) and it patches cleanly. i haven't tried with debian patches.
@lguohan i see build failure in generic arm64. i have pushed a commit now to fix this.
@lguohan builds are passed now. Can you please merge this ?

i took a look at brad patch, the efforts started at 2021 and it is still in the upstream process. 

there are many patches here. i think it falls into two categories, one is pensando soc support, that is the biggest chunk. another category is some driver fixes.

looks like most of the patches can be found in here. https://github.com/pensando/dsc-linux-patches/blob/master/README.md

@ashwin-h , is there any patch in this PR that is not available in the above repo?

> > The feature docker_inram gets the maximum compression ratio when using the zstd algorithm.
> 
> I would have thought LZMA would compresses better?
> 

I ran some benchmark applied to `dockerfs.tar.gz` on all compression algorithms available for `zram`.
```
Algo     Real Size  Comp Size Mem Size  Xtract Xtract+Sync Read  CRatio MRatio
lzo      1633783808 764522544 798195712 28.39  29.31       83.34 3.14   3.05
lzo-rle  1633787904 769651487 803340288 27.88  28.95       83.58 3.12   3.03
zstd     1634697216 573782415 602689536 26.28  66.27       91.68 3.85   3.71
lz4      1633783808 801108972 835792896 25.47  26.39       83.86 3.04   2.95
lz4hc    1634447360 738901758 773656576 39.49  71.14       82.53 3.21   3.11
```

> > On more recent releases sonic releases the crypto/zstd.ko module is built by default.  It is however not the case on sonic-linux-kernel 4.19 which this change addresses.
> 
> Can you reference a commit, where it was turned on?

I never had to enable the config on other releases, I believe the stock debian kernel just enabled `CONFIG_CRYPTO_ZSTD` starting with 5.10.
I can however link the PRs where the `docker_inram` feature was enhanced to use a `zram` device.
master:  https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/15046 (merged)
202205: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/15137 (pending merge)
202012: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/15311 (pending review)

> On what device did you test this?

This was tested on 2 Arista devices `7050QX-32S` and `7060CX-32S` which are products with a small storage size (4GB) and have respectively 4GB and 8GB of RAM.
In this case we enable the `docker_inram` feature and the `dockerfs.tar.gz` is extracted to a `zram` device at initramfs time.

Thank you for the detailed comment. LZMA (XZ) is apparently not supported. The guess regarding Debian’s configuration sounds reasonable.

It’d be great, if you amended the commit message to add all that information.

Sorry for the delay in replying.  I am in the silicon valley, or power was knocked out all week.

 

I’ve reviewed the change, it looks simple and effective, it should work.

 

A couple of notes, regarding the performance impact…

 


No significant time difference is seen related to EEPROM read after adding the current changes. Below stats were taken for a 100G CMIS based


transceiver with making it as optoe3 v/s optoe1


Test stats (average time taken after 3 dumps)


Time to dump first 4096B from EEPROM with transceiver as optoe3 - 914ms


Time to dump first 4096B from EEPROM with transceiver as optoe1 - 911ms

 

If this test was done as a single 4K read, then there was only one read of the ID byte, which would be small compared to the full 4K read.  The impacted case is short reads of pages beyond page 0.  For CMIS devices, page 11 might be read often to check the “Channel state, flags and monitors”.  This is where we find all the alarms and warnings, per channel, for things like TxLOS, Tx CDR LOL, Tx Power High/Low, Tx Bias Current High/Low, etc.  This page might be typically read regularly by health monitoring software, for every device in the switch.  Try running 100 reads of page 11 (EEPROM bytes 1536-1663) to see if the overhead is higher.

 

Note that there should also be a performance impact on QSFP (non-CMIS) devices.  These will also fall into the case that reads the ID register.  Keep in mind that with the patch, optoe3 devices do not suffer the performance impact, so it is appropriate to compare optoe3 vs optoe1 CMIS device performance.  QSFP (non-CMIS) devices will always be impacted by this patch, so the only way to compare performance for true optoe1 devices is between the patched and unpatched drivers.  However…  For QSFP (non-CMIS) devices, there is not much interesting data beyond page 0.  For reads between offset 0 and offset 255, the page checking does not happen.  So there is no performance penalty (CMIS or non_CMIS) for data in the first 256 bytes.  Bottom Line:  In the real world, there should be VERY little accesses beyond byte 255 on QSFP (non-CMIS) devices, so the performance impact on those devices doesn’t really matter.  Don’t bother measuring it.

 

So…  I would like to see the optoe3 vs optoe1 performance impact on a large number of small reads of page 11, rather than on a single read of a large block.

 

Don

So Debian's/Ubuntu's approach to supporting Secure Boot is to sign the kernel after it's built with a shim binary. Could that work here, or is this approach to instead support any arbitrary public key that might be present in the UEFI?
Regarding the `manage-config` script issue, I've raised #300 to fix it.

> So Debian's/Ubuntu's approach to supporting Secure Boot is to sign the kernel after it's built with a shim binary. Could that work here, or is this approach to instead support any arbitrary public key that might be present in the UEFI?

yes,
We are doing the full Secure Boot flow like the Debian approach suggested, using shim, grub, and kernel signed, also the feature is signing kernel modules.
more details can be found in the HLD(link in the description)
And yes, by using shim you can store any arbitrary pub key in the UEFI DB

@saiarcot895 are you ok with the change and can approve it?

> @saiarcot895 are you ok with the change and can approve it?

No. I concur with Guohan's comment.

1. The changes that the new script is making results in modifying files that are tracked in the repo. This means after a build (or even attempted build, in case of a build failure), the git repo's state will be dirty (because there are changes to tracked files).
2. There's nothing undoing these changes after the build is done, meaning if someone switches from a secure boot to non-secure boot environment variable settings, then they'll need to reset the git repo as well.
3. Considering all that is being done is setting some configs (one of which takes in user input), having it be done in `manage-config` makes more sense IMO. `kconfig-secure-boot-inclusions` and `kconfig-secure-boot-exclusions` can be created as well to store the config changes that don't depend on user input.

> 2\. nothing undoing these changes after the build is done, meaning if someone switches from a secure boot to non-secure boot environment variable settings, then they'll need to reset the git repo as well.

I see your point.
1. if there is a fail, the makefile always removes the Linux repo and does wget of the kernel repo fresh. So no see a problem here, pls see the existing code line below from the `Makefile`:
`$(addprefix $(DEST)/, $(MAIN_TARGET)): $(DEST)/% :`
	`# Obtaining the Debian kernel source`
	`rm -rf $(BUILD_DIR)`
3. you are correct about the case of kernel build success because the kernel target file will contain SB (secure boot)kernel flags and will not re-build itself when the user triggers the build again with an unsecured build flags.
4. I'm not sure to move the logic to manage-config will fix the issue (I will try your suggestion locally anway) for the following reason:
The SB depends on the user build configuration because the user needs to decide if SB is enabled or disabled at start of build time.
So I am not sure 100% that creating `kconfig-secure-boot-inclusions` and `kconfig-secure-boot-exclusions` can solve the problem.
The reason is because the kernel configuration that the feature required is not static, it depends on the user configuration selected at the start of the build time.
Maybe until today, the sonic-Linux-kernel supported just static configuration and now we need a new solution that removes the Linux target if some user build flag related was changed?

> if there is a fail, the makefile always removes the Linux repo and does wget of the kernel repo fresh. So no see a problem here

I was referring to the changes done in these lines to `patch/kconfig-inclusions` and `patch/kconfig-exclusions`.

https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linux-kernel/blob/77e18425b9a1ad12cdcb8fc34c09640bea4bb92e/patch/secure_boot_kernel_config.sh#L60-L69

These files are part of the sonic-linux-kernel repo, rather than the Linux kernel repo.

> The SB depends on the user build configuration because the user needs to decide if SB is enabled or disabled at start of build time.
> So I am not sure 100% that creating kconfig-secure-boot-inclusions and kconfig-secure-boot-exclusions can solve the problem.
> The reason is because the kernel configuration that the feature required is not static, it depends on the user configuration selected at the start of the build time.
> Maybe until today, the sonic-Linux-kernel supported just static configuration and now we need a new solution that removes the Linux target if some user build flag related was changed?

I think there's two different things being touched on here. The purpose of creating `kconfig-secure-boot-inclusions` and `kconfig-secure-boot-exclusions` is to have just the static secure boot configs (i.e. everything except `CONFIG_SYSTEM_TRUSTED_KEYS`) in a regular plain-text file, which will then be read in by `manage-config` (similar to how it's reading in `kconfig-inclusions` and `kconfig-exclusions`) and apply the secure boot configs if some argument is passed in. `manage-config` would also separately set `CONFIG_SYSTEM_TRUSTED_KEYS` based on the argument value passed in.

For the kernel build from sonic-buildimage and controlling the configuration, whether the kernel will get rebuilt after it's been already built once depends on the `DEP_FLAGS` for the kernel build:

https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/blob/5e4a866e3311f859b9fe479aa379b38521de9725/rules/linux-kernel.dep#L6-L7

This variable would need to be updated to include the config variable that would be specified in sonic-buildimage to control whether secure boot is enabled and what certificate is used. That way, in a build with caching enabled, if someone switches between having secure boot enabled or disabled, or even different certificate paths, then the kernel will get rebuilt (I don't recall if this is fully checked or not in a build with caching disabled).
